questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky technique

 

Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

 

 

Rokitansky Method

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

 

Ghon’s Method

 

Option B. Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

       

Letulle’s Method

 

Option C. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

 

Virchow’s Method

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rokitansky technique involves dissecting organs in situ and is the preferred method for highly infectious diseases like HIV to prevent the spread of infection.

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

questions.text: Which is the first carpal bone to ossify? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capitate

 

The capitate is the first carpal bone to ossify. The sequence and age of appearance of the carpal bones are important for determining skeletal maturity and age in forensic examinations.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Lunate: Appears at 4 years of age.

 

Option C. Hamate: Appears at 2 months of age, just after the capitate.

 

Option D. Scaphoid: Appears at 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age of appearance of carpal bones is given below:

 

 

Mnemonic:

 

  • Capitate is captain, hence comes first
  • Hamate sound like capitate, so comes immediately after it
  • Triquetral: Tri implies 3
  • Pisiform is Laziform so comes last

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Incisions

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound (incisions, suction, rubbing, tattooing, vigorous cleaning, massage, application of herbs or chemicals, cryotherapy, cautery) as this may introduce infection, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Reassurance: Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites, the patient can be saved the risk of death is not immediate. If the patient gets panicked his heart rate would increase which in term would spread the venom rapidly.

 

Option B) Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite: Detailed history will be helpful to know the type of snake Detailed history in snakebite is essential to delineate treatment options moving forward. Information to obtain includes the timing and location of bite, the onset of any symptoms, and any first aid administered in field. Take a past medical history with detail to which medications they are on, especially anti-platelet / anti-coagulant medications, and any allergies that would prohibit from receiving antivenom.

 

Option C) Go to hospital: Main treatment of snake bite can be given in hospital only (Anti-snake venom, airway maintenance, fluids etc.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the boy. Identify the approximate age of the girl from the Xray picture of her pelvis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 21 years

 

The ischial tuberosity in the X ray is fused, hence the age is > 21 years

 

Some students can get confused and are not able to distinguish whether ischial tuberosity has fused or not yet appeared. It is not possible that ischial tuberosity has not yet appeared because the upper end of femur (head, greater trochanter, lesser trochanter) has fused with shaft which occurs between 17- 19 years, whereas ischial tuberosity appears earlier at 16 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Femur

 

Upper end of Femur is composed of three centres:

 

  • Head – 1 yr (A)             
  • Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)
  • Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)          

 

These three centres fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis

questions.text: All the following are used for identification of a dead body except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nail

 

Less commonly used due to challenges in extracting sufficient DNA unless recent under-nail samples are available for identifying substances or DNA remnants.

 

Other Options:

 

The various tissues used for identification of a deceased individual vary in their utility and reliability.

 

Option A. Muscle: Can be used for DNA profiling, especially when other tissues are degraded.

 

Option B. Blood: Highly useful for DNA extraction and toxicological analysis to help in identification and determining cause of death.

 

Option D. Hair: Useful if the hair contains follicles; provides DNA which can be crucial for identification purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While nails can sometimes provide useful information, such as traces of substances the individual may have been in contact with, they are less reliable for DNA-based identification compared to other tissues like blood or hair with follicles.

questions.text: A 51-year-old bomb blast victim is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries. There was a lot of chaos and no one was available to sign consent for emergency surgery. Despite surgery the patient died. The doctor is not responsible under which doctrine? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doctrine of anticipation 

 

Core Concept

 

Operating without consent in life threatening emergency

 

  • IPC Section 92 - Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
  • This means that the doctor can perform life-saving procedures in a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent specially if delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. 
  • This is also called as the doctrine of anticipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Res ipsa loquitur:

 

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • Here the Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.
  • The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence

 

Option C. Doctrine of extended consent: suppose some another pathology is discovered during surgery then another consent is taken. This is called doctrine of extended consent

 

Option D. Doctrine of conjugated consent: Consent for multiple procedures given together

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Doctrine of anticipation," which permits medical interventions without prior consent in emergencies where delays could result in harm or death to the patient. This doctrine is crucial in understanding the legal protections afforded to doctors making critical decisions under duress and with the intent to save lives.

choices.text: Hepatotoxicity, GI irritation, metabolic acidosis, bowel obstruction
GI irritation, latent phase, shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis
Bowel obstruction, GI irritation, shock, recovery from GI symptoms
Latent phase, metabolic acidosis, GI irritation, hepatotoxicity

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by his parents after accidentally ingesting several iron tablets. Based on the progression of iron toxicity, arrange the symptoms in the correct order as they typically appear during the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. GI irritation, latent phase, shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis

 

Explanation:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several distinct stages, starting with initial gastrointestinal (GI) irritation that occurs within 30 minutes to 6 hours of ingestion. This stage is marked by symptoms like vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Following this, the latent phase (Stage II) occurs between 6 to 24 hours, during which GI symptoms may temporarily subside, misleading caregivers into thinking the patient is recovering. However, this is followed by Stage III, which involves shock and metabolic acidosis, occurring between 6 to 72 hours, characterized by severe systemic symptoms such as dehydration, shock, and lactic acidosis. Stage IV, occurring between 12 to 96 hours, involves hepatotoxicity and hepatic necrosis, which can lead to liver failure. Finally, Stage V involves GI mucosal healing leading to scarring and bowel obstruction, which can occur weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Hepatotoxicity, GI irritation, metabolic acidosis, bowel obstruction: This order is incorrect as it suggests hepatotoxicity precedes GI irritation, which does not align with the progression of iron toxicity stages.

 

C. Bowel obstruction, GI irritation, shock, recovery from GI symptoms: This sequence incorrectly places bowel obstruction as the initial event, whereas it occurs much later in the toxicity progression, after the acute systemic effects.

D. Latent p

hase, metabolic acidosis, GI irritation, hepatotoxicity: This order is incorrect because GI irritation is the first stage, not preceded by the latent phase or metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through five stages: initial GI irritation, a deceptive latent phase, severe systemic effects including shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis, and finally, late-onset bowel obstruction due to scarring. Recognizing the sequence of these stages is crucial for timely intervention and management in cases of acute iron overdose.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel, and after a few months, she presents with easy fatiguability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anemia. Which of the following bowel resections is least likely to cause this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

The clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency. The resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause this condition. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, and intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach is necessary for its absorption. Vitamin B12 is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia with a peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil. In contrast, the jejunum is mainly used in folic acid absorption, and the stomach and ileum are involved in the absorption of vitamin B12.

 

While the duodenum contributes to overall nutrient absorption, vitamin B12 absorption is mainly absorbed in the ileum. So, resection of the duodenum alone might not as severely impact vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Resection of the jejunum can potentially lead to malabsorption of folic acid, as this is primarily absorbed in the jejunum or ileum.

 

Option C. Ileum: The ileum is a significant site for the absorption of vitamin B12 and is also involved in folic acid absorption. Resection of the ileum can severely disrupt the absorption of these nutrients, leading to macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Stomach: The stomach is the site for production of intrinsic factor, required for B12 absorption.

choices.text: Sexual assault done by police officer

questions.text: According to POCSO, aggravated sexual assault includes: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sexual assault done by police officer

 

An offence is treated as ‘aggravated’ when committed by a person in a position of trust or authority of child, such as a member of security forces, police officer, public servant, etc.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Threatening: it comes under sexual harassment in POCSO and not under aggravated sexual assault.

 

Option C) Gang penetrative sexual assault comes under aggravated penetrative sexual assault and not under aggravated sexual assault. Therefore, it cannot be correct in this case.

 

Option D) All of the above: since Option A and Option B are incorrect, it cannot be the answer.

 

Educational objective

 

POCSO

 

The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  6. ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

 

When it comes to aggravated sexual assault, the crime must involve certain aggravating factors. For example: 

 

  • By a person in a position of the authority such as a police officer, relative, doctor
  • In the course of communal violence
  • On mentally & physically disabled
  • Gang sexual assault
  • Using deadly weapons
  • Causing grievous hurt

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligature mark

 

A ligature mark is a well-known pressure mark on the neck underneath a ligature. It is a common injury in cases of hanging and strangulation.

 

Ligature Mark:

 

  • Appearance: Typically presents as a horizontal or slightly diagonal mark around the neck.
  • Cause: Caused by the application of a ligature (e.g., rope, cord, or similar object) under tension.
  • Context: Commonly associated with homicidal, suicidal, or accidental hanging and strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graze abrasion: Caused by scraping or sliding friction against a rough surface, resulting in superficial loss of skin.

 

Option C. Brush burns: Result from friction burns, often appearing as red, inflamed, and abraded areas of skin.

 

Option D. Imprint abrasion: Caused by the impact of a patterned object, leaving an imprint on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Types of abrasions:

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Signs of Cocaine intoxication:

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Myocardial ischemia: Cocaine can induce myocardial ischemia due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties on coronary arteries.

 

Option C. Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia is a common symptom of cocaine intoxication due to increased metabolic activity and muscle activity.

 

Option D. Agitation: Agitation is a well-known effect of cocaine's stimulant properties on the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine poisoning typically causes increased heart rate (tachycardia) rather than bradycardia, along with other symptoms like myocardial ischemia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Belladona

 

The symptoms described, including dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate, and dilated pupils, are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. Belladonna, contains tropane alkaloids with anticholinergic effects. Features of belladonna are same as that of Datura, and both belong to Solanaceae family.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Heroin: It is an Opioid (CNS depressant) and have symptoms such as sedation, coma, decreased vitas (respiratory depression, low BP, low Heart rate, low temperature), and miosis. Whereas in the question there is high pulse rate, and dilated pupils.

 

Option B) Morphine: is also an Opioid, and will have similar features as that of heroin.

 

Option C) Malathion: is an organophosphate insecticide. It will have cholinergic symptoms, like Diarrhea, urination excessive, miosis, bradycardia, emesis, lachrymation, and salivation (Mnemonic DUMBELS). These are exactly opposite of those mentioned in question.

 

Educational Objective

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus Niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae
  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.
  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.
  • Sign and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms. So, Atropa belladonna will also have features same as that of Datura: Dry hot skin, Dilatated pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Decreased Body Secretions, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium
  • Treatment is Physostigmine
  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective

 

The Barberio test detects the presence of spermine from semen by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, making it the correct test for the described scenario.

choices.text: Asphyxia
Vagal inhibition
Laryngospasm
Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laryngospasm

 

Option C. Laryngospasm : In cases of dry drowning, laryngospasm is a reflex closure of the vocal cords and other airway muscles that occurs when water touches the vocal cords or throat. This spasm can seal the airway, preventing water from entering the lungs but also air, leading to suffocation.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asphyxia : In typical drowning cases, this happens when water fills the lungs, preventing oxygen from reaching the blood. However, it isn't the direct cause in dry drowning.

 

Option B. Vagal Inhibition : This refers to a sudden stop of the heart due to a reflex action stimulated by extreme stress or shock, particularly cold water impacting the face. It can instantly stop heart activity but is rare.

 

Option D. Ventricular Fibrillation : Ventricular fibrillation is a severe cardiac rhythm disturbance where the heart's electrical activity becomes so chaotic that the heart stops pumping effectively, leading to sudden cardiac death. It can happen due to severe hypoxia from drowning.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry drowning is characterized by a laryngospasm that prevents water from entering the lungs but leads to death through asphyxia due to a blocked airway.

questions.text: A doctor mistakenly uses the same needle on two patients, one of whom is HIV-positive. The second patient subsequently tests positive for HIV. Under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the doctor liable for this act of negligence? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Section 269

 

Explanation:

 

Section 269 of the IPC specifically addresses negligent acts that are likely to spread infection or disease dangerous to life. In this scenario, the doctor's reuse of a contaminated needle is a clear act of negligence that directly led to the transmission of HIV, a life-threatening disease, to the second patient.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Section 166B: This section pertains to punishment for a public servant disobeying a direction of the law with intent to cause injury to any person. While the doctor's action may be considered a violation of medical protocols, it doesn't directly fall under this section.
  • Section 202: This section addresses the intentional omission to give information of an offense by a person legally bound to inform. It's not relevant in this case where the act was negligent, not intentional.
  • Section 203: Similar to Section 202, this section deals with giving false information regarding an offense, which is not applicable to this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Section 269 of the IPC is crucial in addressing cases of medical negligence where a healthcare provider's actions lead to the spread of infectious diseases. It highlights the importance of adhering to infection control practices to prevent the transmission of communicable diseases.

questions.text: What is the postmortem sign in which a gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Robert‘s sign

 

Robert sign refers to the presence of a gas shadow within the heart or the greater vessels, in cases of fetal death in utero. It is a rare sign caused by postmortem blood degeneration, usually seen 1-2 days after death; and may be seen as early as 12 hours.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Spalding sign – overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by collapse of the fetal brain.

 

Option C. Ball sign - hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

 

Option D. Halo sign - increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault.

 

Educational objective

 

Roberts sign is characterized by the presence of gas shadows in the heart or great vessels of a fetus, indicating intrauterine demise and typically appearing 1-2 days postmortem.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

As a result of parallel rays being focused in front of the retina in the image above, myopia is indicated as the refractive error.

 

Myopia, also referred to as "short sight," is a dioptric condition of the eye in which incident parallel rays focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina while accommodation is at rest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presbyopia: It is an age-related condition characterized by a gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects, due to the hardening of the lens inside the eye.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: Also known as farsightedness, in this condition, light rays entering the eye focus behind the retina. Individuals with hypermetropia see distant objects more clearly than close ones.

 

 

 

Option D. Astigmatism: This refractive error occurs due to an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to be focused at multiple points in front of, on, or behind the retina, leading to blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia results from the focusing of light in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry, a condition often corrected with concave lenses.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

choices.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is done in primary survey
X-rays in primary survey may also be done in pregnant women

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

 

Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

 

This statement is false. Chest X-rays are often a standard part of the primary survey to assess for chest injuries and potential life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax or hemothorax, however AP view is commonly used in the primary survey. PA view requires patient to be standing, which is usually not possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for CT scans: This statement is true. Hemodynamically unstable patients are in a critical condition, and their immediate management should prioritize stabilizing their condition.

 

Option C. X-ray of the pelvis is done in the primary survey: This statement is true. Pelvic X-rays may be performed if pelvic injury is suspected based on clinical assessment, however they are not universally conducted in all trauma patients during the primary survey, hence considered as “adjuncts”.

 

Option D. X-rays in the primary survey may be done in pregnant women: This statement is generally true. Pregnant trauma patients should undergo imaging as needed during the primary survey to assess for injuries. However, the choice of imaging modalities and the use of shielding techniques should consider the safety of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

 

  • Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan

 

ABCDE of trauma care:

 

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey are-

 

  • Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheterization
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

 

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient presents with an BT leprosy lesion on the face as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facial Nerve

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests a case of leprosy, with the facial nerve being the most commonly affected cranial nerve.

 

  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which impacts the mucous membranes, cutaneous tissues, and peripheral nerves leading to sensory and motor deficits.

 

Most commonly affected nerves:

 

  • Peripheral nerves: Ulnar > Posterior tibial nerve, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • Cranial nerves: Facial nerve > Trigeminal nerve.
  • Notably, facial skin lesions are associated with a 10-fold increase in the risk of facial nerve involvement in leprosy cases.
  • Facial nerve involvement can lead to facial muscle weakness, paralysis, and loss of facial expressions, which are characteristic features of this condition.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) primarily innervates the face and is responsible for sensations such as touch and pain.
  • While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the most commonly involved nerve in BT leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve:

 

  • The abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
  • In leprosy, it is less commonly involved compared to the facial nerve, especially in BT leprosy.

 

Option D. Optic nerve:

 

The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and is not commonly affected in leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve (option A).

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 28, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: All of the following artery demonstrates Windkessel effect except: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial artery

 

Radial artery can show Windkessel effect, but among the given options, it is the most peripheral artery. As we move from center to periphery the elasticity property in the artery decreases, hence least Windkessel effect is seen in the radial artery hence it is the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal artery: The renal artery demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its proximity to the aorta and its elastic properties.

 

Option C. Aorta: The aorta is a primary example of a vessel demonstrating the Windkessel effect.

 

Option D. Carotid artery:  The carotid artery also demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its elastic properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINDKESSEL VESSELS

 

Large elastic arteries contain Elastin protein → elastic recoil

 

Ex: - Aorta & large arteries (e.g. Pulmonary Artery, Carotid, Renal artery)

 

  • During systole → Ventricle → eject blood → aorta gets stretched
  • During Diastole → Aortic recoil → DBP
  • At old age → Aortic stenosis → elasticity → hardening of aorta → SBP →DBP→PP

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

 

Explanation:

 

The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint.  .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.

 

Option C. Distal end of radius: The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:

 

  • Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum

 

Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methanol

 

Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

 

 

Compound fixatives are mixtures of reagents. Eg: alcoholic formalin fixes tissues in two ways i.e firstly, by adding covalent hydroxymethyl groups and crosslinking proteins and secondly, by coagulation and dehydration.

 

Crosslinking fixatives, on the other hand, work by forming covalent bonds between proteins and other molecules, stabilizing the tissue structure and preserving the morphology for microscopic examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutaraldehyde: A crosslinking fixative that forms stable covalent bonds between proteins, commonly used in electron microscopy.

 

Option B. Formaldehyde: Another crosslinking fixative, often used in light microscopy, that preserves tissues by forming crosslinks between proteins.

 

Option D. Osmium tetroxide: A crosslinking fixative used primarily in electron microscopy to preserve and ultrastructural visualization of cell membranes, as an additive for post-fixation after glutaraldehyde.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol is a dehydrant coagulant fixative and does not function as a crosslinking fixative like glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, or osmium tetroxide.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells)

questions.text: A child is brought to OPD with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Patient reported that it initially started as macule and later developed to become nodules. On examination, you noticed that some nodules have central umbilication. Microscopy finding is shown below. Identify the finding: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells): These are typically seen in herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and are not related to molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option B. Donovan bodies: These are characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Koilocytes: These are squamous epithelial cells that have undergone specific changes due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, are pathognomonic for molluscum contagiosum, a poxvirus infection.

questions.text: NARP syndrome is a? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial function disorder

 

NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as a mitochondrial function disorder.

 

NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. Most individuals with NARP have a specific MT-ATP6 genetic change in 70 percent to 90 percent of their mitochondria. NARP syndrome is inherited from the mother (maternal inheritance) because only females pass mitochondrial DNA to their children.

 

It has 2 phenotypes:

 

  • NARP
  • Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS)

 

It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial DNA load in the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosomal storage disorder: Lysosomal storage disorders result from defects in lysosomal function, leading to the accumulation of undigested macromolecules. Examples include Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher disease. NARP syndrome is not related to lysosomal function.

 

Option C. Glycogen storage disorder: Glycogen storage disorders involve defects in the metabolism of glycogen, leading to its accumulation in tissues. Examples include Pompe disease and McArdle disease. NARP syndrome is not a glycogen storage disorder.

 

Option D. Golgi body transport disorder: Disorders of the Golgi apparatus involve defects in protein and lipid processing and trafficking. Examples include congenital disorders of glycosylation. NARP syndrome is not related to Golgi body transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NARP syndrome is a mitochondrial function disorder caused by a point mutation in the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene, leading to a spectrum of neurological and retinal symptoms.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 2572

choices.text: Inhibition of calcineurin
AMP kinase stimulation
IMP dehydrogenase inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin
 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that acts by inhibiting Calcineurin.
  • Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation.
  • Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin.
  • This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2 and other factors.
  • Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.
  • Indications: It is the most effective drug for the prevention of Graft rejection reaction. It is also used as a second line drug in autoimmune disease like severe Rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, inflammatory bowel disease and dermatomyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMP kinase is stimulated by metformin used in treating T2DM
 

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil, also used in the prophylaxis of transplant rejection.

 

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is inhibited by leflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor indicated for the management of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Deep y descent in Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) is seen in all of the following conditions except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

 

Deep y descent in JVP (Jugular venous pressure) is a characteristic finding in several conditions that affect the filling of the right ventricle. These conditions include constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Cardiac tamponade, as it is associated with a blunted y descent in JVP rather than a deep y descent. In cardiac tamponade, the pericardial fluid accumulation restricts cardiac filling, leading to a decrease in the amplitude of the y descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition can cause a deep y descent due to the stiff ventricular walls allowing rapid passive filling only during early diastole.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Similar to restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis also shows a rapid early diastolic filling as the rigid pericardium constricts ventricular filling in late diastole, leading to a pronounced y descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: In tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial emptying occurs without the normal resistance posed by a competent tricuspid valve, often resulting in a prominent y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the presence of fluid in the pericardial space restricts all phases of cardiac filling, leading to a blunted or absent y descent, differentiating it from conditions where a deep y descent is observed.

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

 

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital birth defect characterized by a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, which leads to the evisceration of the bowel loops which are not covered by a sac and are exposed to the external environment. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.

 

Congenital umbilical hernia: Umbilical hernia is a protrusion of the abdominal contents through a weakness in the umbilical ring, and ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital anomaly in which the urinary bladder is located outside the abdominal cavity.

 

 

Option B. Umbilical hernia: In case of umbilical hernia we do not usually see content of bowel coming out. Umbilical hernia is a cystic swelling which regresess when the baby is sleeping & appears during crying. No treatment is required for such condition.

 

Option D. Ectopia vesicae: Ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital malformation where the urinary bladder is located outside the lower abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other abnormalities of the urinary tract and reproductive system. Ectopia vesicae is typically noticed at birth, and its severity can vary depending on the specific case

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by the herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, without a protective sac covering the contents.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. On examination, she is drowsy with a pulse rate of 130/min and a respiratory rate of 28/min. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals severe metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.15. Urine analysis shows the presence of calcium oxalate crystals. Based on these findings, what is the most likely cause of her poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Ethylene glycol

 

Explanation:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which are key diagnostic findings. Ethylene glycol, commonly found in antifreeze, is metabolized into toxic metabolites, including glycolic acid and oxalic acid, which contribute to metabolic acidosis and can lead to renal failure. The deposition of calcium oxalate crystals in the kidneys further impairs renal function and is a hallmark of ethylene glycol toxicity. Symptoms often include drowsiness, tachycardia, and rapid breathing due to the acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Methanol: Methanol poisoning also causes metabolic acidosis and visual disturbances but does not typically result in calcium oxalate crystal formation in the urine. Methanol is primarily metabolized into formic acid, leading to ocular toxicity and acidosis without the renal crystal deposition seen in ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

B. Isopropyl alcohol: Isopropyl alcohol ingestion leads to central nervous system depression and the presence of acetone in the blood, causing fruity breath odor. It does not cause metabolic acidosis or the formation of calcium oxalate crystals, distinguishing it from ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

D. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, confusion, and cherry-red skin but does not cause metabolic acidosis or calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. It primarily impairs oxygen delivery by binding to hemoglobin, resulting in hypoxia rather than renal effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which is pathognomonic for this type of poisoning. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent severe renal impairment and other systemic complications associated with ethylene glycol toxicity.

choices.text: Continue same diet

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue same diet

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half. During the first trimester, there is no need for additional calories. The caloric increase is recommended as follows:

 

  • 0 Kcal in 1st trimester
  • 340 Kcal in 2nd trimester
  • 452 Kcal in 3rd trimester

 

In this question, extra calories in the 1st trimester are asked, so the answer will be no additional requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Page no 487, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

 

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. This modification is gamma carboxylation, which allows these proteins to bind calcium ions and participate effectively in the coagulation cascade.

 

Vitamin K Dependent Factors:

 

  • Procoagulants: Factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X.
  • Anticoagulants: Protein C and Protein S.

 

These factors are synthesized in the liver and require gamma carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues for their activity. Without this modification, they cannot bind calcium effectively, which is necessary for their role in coagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

questions.text: Dr. Rathi, an obstetrician in a suburban Indian clinic, was counseling Mrs. Mehta, a software engineer, on nutritional needs during pregnancy. Mrs. Mehta has a sedentary desk job and is entering her second trimester. The doctor emphasized the significance of an appropriate caloric intake to ensure both maternal and fetal health. Given her lifestyle and the stage of pregnancy, by how much should Mrs. Mehta ideally increase her daily caloric consumption? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 350 kcal/day

 

The suggested daily calorie intake for a pregnant woman in a sedentary occupation should be raised by approximately 350 calories.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy Additional Energy Requirements:
    • +350 kcal/day
  • Lactation Additional Energy Requirements:
    • 0-6 m: +600 kcal/day
    • 6-12 m: +520 kcal/day

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

choices.text: Microfractures in the sub-epiphyseal region
Bucket handle fractures of metaphyses

questions.text: Which of the following findings is NOT suggestive of child abuse? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Wormian bones

 

Explanation:

 

Wormian bones are extra bone pieces within the skull sutures. While they can be a normal variant, they are also associated with certain genetic conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease). They are not typically indicative of child abuse.

 

The other options are highly suggestive of child abuse:

 

  • Microfractures in the sub-epiphyseal region: These tiny fractures near the growth plate are often caused by forceful twisting or shaking of a child's limb.
  • Corner fractures: Also known as bucket-handle fractures, these fractures occur at the metaphysis (the growing part of a long bone) and are highly specific for child abuse, often resulting from violent shaking or pulling.
  • Bucket handle fractures of metaphyses: This is another term for corner fractures, emphasizing their characteristic appearance on X-rays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While several skeletal injuries are strong indicators of child abuse, Wormian bones are not. They are more commonly associated with genetic conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: The given chemical structure is of: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondroitin sulphate

 

Chondroitin sulphate is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Keratan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine.
  • Location: Found in cartilage, cornea, and intervertebral discs.

 

Option C. Heparin:

  • Composition: Contains glucuronic acid or iduronic acid and glucosamine.
  • Location: Primarily found in mast cells and used as an anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Dermatan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine.
  • Location: Found in skin, blood vessels, and heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chondroitin sulphate is a glycosaminoglycan found in connective tissues like cartilage and bone, characterized by its repeating units of glucuronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstructive disease

 

A reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. This ratio is a key indicator used to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung patterns on pulmonary function tests. In obstructive diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis, there is a disproportionate reduction in FEV1 relative to FVC due to airflow limitation and air trapping.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive disease: In restrictive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, often leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Restrictive diseases include conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis and other interstitial lung diseases.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal lung function would typically show an FEV1/FVC ratio within the normal range, which is generally above 0.7 in healthy adults.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: This condition is a type of restrictive lung disease where there is a reduction in lung volumes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FEV1/FVC reduction implies obstruction.
  • FEV1/FVC Increased or normal – Restrictive lung disease
  • Decrease in Maximum Mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) i.e., FEV25%-75% - Small airway disease

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing various constitutional provisions to understand which ones directly address the welfare and protection of children. During this review, the pediatrician identifies one article that primarily deals with workers' rights and maternity relief rather than focusing on children's care. Which of the following constitutional articles is not directly related to pediatric care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Article 42

 

Explanation:

 

Article 42 of the constitution is concerned with securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief, focusing on the welfare of workers, especially women, by ensuring proper working conditions and maternity benefits. Although it indirectly benefits children through maternity support, it does not specifically address pediatric care or child welfare. Articles like 21A, 45, and 47 focus on child-specific needs, such as education, nutrition, and overall welfare, which are more directly related to pediatric care.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Article 45: Article 45 directs the state to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years. It specifically addresses the needs of young children and directly relates to pediatric care and development.

 

B. Article 47: Article 47 imposes a duty on the state to raise the level of nutrition, standard of living, and public health, including that of children. It focuses on the overall health and well-being of the population, including pediatric concerns.

 

D. Article 21A: Article 21A mandates the right to free and compulsory education for children aged 6 to 14 years, directly addressing the educational rights of children, making it directly relevant to their welfare and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is primarily focused on working conditions and maternity relief and does not specifically address pediatric care, unlike Articles 21A, 45, and 47, which are directly aimed at the welfare, education, and health of children. Understanding the scope of these constitutional articles helps in identifying which provisions are designed to protect and promote child health and welfare.

questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prussian blue  

 

Perl's iron stain is the classic method for demonstrating iron in tissues. The section is treated with dilute hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins. These ions then react with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

 

 

Used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, lead toxicity to visualize iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts and myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Masson's trichrome: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and other tissue components. It stains collagen fibers blue or green, muscle fibers red, and cytoplasm light red or pink. It is not used for detecting iron.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS stain is primarily used to detect glycogen and other polysaccharides in tissues. It stains these components magenta. PAS is not useful for detecting iron in tissues.

 

Option D. Fite-Faraco: This is a special stain used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. It is not used for staining iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:
